Which Splines Do You Need? A Comprehensive Dive into Common Splines

Sulley
2023-05-03
数学 - 图形学
Curve, Spline, 动画, 插值, 数学, 曲线, 计算机, 随笔

This post introduces some widely used splines in computer games including Bézier curves, cubic Hermite splines, Catmull-Rom splines, B-splines, Kochanek–Bartels splines, etc. We show these splines can be bridged through re-formulation. Then, we focus on the extension and generalization of Bézier curves and introduce mathematical methods to create dynamic smooth splines. Last, we develop a simple Editor in Unreal Engine to enable easy creation of splines under different constraints and conditions.

Common Splines

Bézier Curve

The most typical and widely-used spline might be Bézier curves. Bézier curve leverages a set of control points to define a smooth and continuous curve generated by interpolation between these control points. Using the De Casteljau’s algorithm,[1] we can easily express a Bézier curve in terms of a sum of Bernstein polynomials:

B(t)=∑i=0npibi,n(t), bi,n(t)=(ni)(1−t)n−iti\mathbf{B}(t)=\sum_{i=0}^n\mathbf{p}_ib_{i,n}(t), ~b_{i,n}(t)=\binom{n}{i}(1-t)^{n-i}t^i B(t)=i=0∑n​pi​bi,n​(t), bi,n​(t)=(in​)(1−t)n−iti

When there are four control points, the generated curve is called cubic Bézier curve. A cubic Bézier curve can be expanded as:

B(t)=(1−t)3p0+3(1−t)2tp1+3(1−t)t2p2+t3p3, 0≤t≤1\mathbf{B}(t)=(1-t)^3\mathbf{p}_0+3(1-t)^2t\mathbf{p}_1+3(1-t)t^2\mathbf{p}_2+t^3\mathbf{p}_3,~0\le t\le 1 B(t)=(1−t)3p0​+3(1−t)2tp1​+3(1−t)t2p2​+t3p3​, 0≤t≤1

The derivative of an nnn-th order curve is:

Similarly, we can obtain the second-order derivative:

We will use these results later soon.

Degree elevation

Suppose B(t)\mathbf{B}(t)B(t) is an nnn-th order Bézier curve and we want to elevate its degree to n+1n+1n+1. We can do this via the following process:

Note that when i=0i=0i=0, p0′=p0\mathbf{p}'_0=\mathbf{p}_0p0′​=p0​, and when i=n+1i=n+1i=n+1, pn+1′=pn\mathbf{p}'_{n+1}=\mathbf{p}_npn+1′​=pn​. So p−1\mathbf{p}_{-1}p−1​ and pn+1\mathbf{p}_{n+1}pn+1​ can be arbitrary. We simply set them to zero.

Composite Bézier curves

A composite Bézier curve is a series of Bézier curves joined end to end where the first point of one curve coincides with the last point of the previous curve. If a Bézier curve is composite, we say it’s C0\mathsf{C}^0C0 continuous.

However, sometimes we want higher degrees of continuity than C0\mathsf{C}^0C0 at the joint of Bézier curves (note that individual curves are C∞\mathsf{C}^\inftyC∞ within their own inteval, and the discontinuity only happens at the meetings of consecutive curves).

Given two Bézier curves [p0,p1,p2,p3][\mathbf{p}_0,\mathbf{p}_1,\mathbf{p}_2,\mathbf{p}_3][p0​,p1​,p2​,p3​] and [p3,p4,p5,p6][\mathbf{p}_3,\mathbf{p}_4,\mathbf{p}_5,\mathbf{p}_6][p3​,p4​,p5​,p6​], we can define different degrees of continuity at p3\mathbf{p}_3p3​:

  • C0/G0\mathsf{C}^0/\mathsf{G}^0C0/G0 (positional continuity): consecutive Bézier curves meet at the same point. This holds by definition. In this case, it’s p3\mathbf{p}_3p3​.

  • C1\mathsf{C}^1C1 (velocity continuity): the incoming and outgoing derivatives of p3\mathbf{p}_3p3​ are the same, vouching for a smooth transition from the first curve to the second. To show this, we let B′(1)first=B′(0)second\mathbf{B}'(1)_\text{first}=\mathbf{B}'(0)_\text{second}B′(1)first​=B′(0)second​, and the solution is 3(p3−p2)=3(p4−p3)3(\mathbf{p}_3-\mathbf{p}_2)=3(\mathbf{p}_4-\mathbf{p}_3)3(p3​−p2​)=3(p4​−p3​). This gives us 2p3=p2+p42\mathbf{p}_3=\mathbf{p}_2+\mathbf{p}_42p3​=p2​+p4​. This equation tells us that p2\mathbf{p}_2p2​ and p4\mathbf{p}_4p4​ are not only colinear with respect to p3\mathbf{p}_3p3​, but their vector lengths are also the same. Rewriting this equation to p4=2p3−p2\mathbf{p}_4 = 2\mathbf{p}_3-\mathbf{p}_2p4​=2p3​−p2​ suggests p4\mathbf{p}_4p4​ is fully determined by p2\mathbf{p}_2p2​ and p3\mathbf{p}_3p3​ if we want C1\mathsf{C}^1C1 continuity.

  • G1\mathsf{G}^1G1 (tangent continuity): p2\mathbf{p}_2p2​ and p4\mathbf{p}_4p4​ are colinear but not requiring their vector lengths to be equal. Thus, we say G1\mathsf{G}^1G1 is less strict than C1\mathsf{C}^1C1. If a composite curve is C1\mathsf{C}^1C1, then it must be G1\mathsf{G}^1G1. To guarantee G1\mathsf{G}^1G1, we just add an extra degree of freedom to the vector length: p4=p3+β(p3−p2) (β>0)\mathbf{p}_4=\mathbf{p}_3+\beta(\mathbf{p}_3-\mathbf{p}_2)~(\beta>0)p4​=p3​+β(p3​−p2​) (β>0). G1\mathsf{G}^1G1 means the two curves share a common tangent direction at the join point.

  • C2\mathsf{C}^2C2 (acceleration continuity): following a similar process to C1\mathsf{C}^1C1 continuity, the C2\mathsf{C}^2C2 continuity can be defined by p5=p1+4(p3−p2)\mathbf{p}_5=\mathbf{p}_1+4(\mathbf{p}_3-\mathbf{p}_2)p5​=p1​+4(p3​−p2​). That is to say, p5\mathbf{p}_5p5​ is fully determined by p1,p2\mathbf{p}_1, \mathbf{p}_2p1​,p2​ and p3\mathbf{p}_3p3​. You should be very careful of using C2\mathsf{C}^2C2 continuity: the C2\mathsf{C}^2C2 continuity causes a loss of two control points p4\mathbf{p}_4p4​ and p5\mathbf{p}_5p5​, leaving only one free control point p6\mathbf{p}_6p6​. You perhaps cannot get the curve shape you expect. If you do not want to loss control over these points, you can use uniform B-splines, which will be introduced later.

  • G2\mathsf{G}^2G2 (curvature continuity): this type of continuity requires kB′′(1)first=B′′(0)second (k>0)k\mathbf{B}''(1)_\text{first}=\mathbf{B}''(0)_\text{second}~(k>0)kB′′(1)first​=B′′(0)second​ (k>0) except requiring G1\mathsf{G}^1G1, i.e., satisfying p5=p3+(p3−p2)(2β1+β12+β2/2)+(p1−p2)β12\mathbf{p}_5=\mathbf{p}_3+(\mathbf{p}_3-\mathbf{p}_2)(2\beta_1+\beta_1^2+\beta_2/2)+(\mathbf{p}_1-\mathbf{p}_2)\beta^2_1p5​=p3​+(p3​−p2​)(2β1​+β12​+β2​/2)+(p1​−p2​)β12​. To obtain this result, first expand kB′′(1)first=B′′(0)secondk\mathbf{B}''(1)_\text{first}=\mathbf{B}''(0)_\text{second}kB′′(1)first​=B′′(0)second​ and then plug p4=p3+β(p3−p2)\mathbf{p}_4=\mathbf{p}_3+\beta(\mathbf{p}_3-\mathbf{p}_2)p4​=p3​+β(p3​−p2​) in. Last, substitute for kkk with β12\beta_1^2β12​ and β\betaβ with β1+β2/4\beta_1+\beta_2/4β1​+β2​/4, and you will get the right formula. Curvature continuity implies that the curves share a common center of curvature at the join point.

  • C3\mathsf{C}^3C3 (jolt continuity): if a composite Bézier curve is C3\mathsf{C}^3C3, it satisfies p6=p3+(p3−p0)+6(p1−2p2+p3)\mathbf{p}_6=\mathbf{p}_3+(\mathbf{p}_3-\mathbf{p}_0)+6(\mathbf{p}_1-2\mathbf{p}_2+\mathbf{p}_3)p6​=p3​+(p3​−p0​)+6(p1​−2p2​+p3​). In this case, the fist curve full determines the second curve and thus the third, forth curve, etc. Now we say the generated composite Bézier curve is C∞\mathsf{C}^\inftyC∞ as there is indeed no joins.

If a curve is Cn\mathsf{C}^nCn, then it must be Gn\mathsf{G}^nGn. If a curve is Cn/Gn\mathsf{C}^n/\mathsf{G}^nCn/Gn, then it must be Cn−1/Gn−1\mathsf{C}^{n-1}/\mathsf{G}^{n-1}Cn−1/Gn−1.

Rational Bézier curves

The Bezier curve will be fully determined if we specify a particlar type of continuity, say, G2\mathsf{G}^2G2. In such case, we cannot easily control the shape of the curve because all control points all equally weighted. We want to give it a little more flexibility: when we assign a larger weight to one point, the curve will bend more to that point. We call this type of Bezier curve as rational Bezier curve, which can be defined as:

B(t)=∑i=0npibi,n(t)wi∑i=0nbi,n(t)wi, 0≤t≤1\mathbf{B}(t)=\frac{\sum_{i=0}^n\mathbf{p}_ib_{i,n}(t)w_i}{\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w_i}, ~0\le t\le 1 B(t)=∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)wi​∑i=0n​pi​bi,n​(t)wi​​, 0≤t≤1

where wi>0w_i>0wi​>0 is the weight associated with each control point pi\mathbf{p}_ipi​. It is clear from the definition that, when all weights are equal, it regresses to a standard nnn-degree Bezier curve.

An interesting fact about an nnn-degree rational Bezier curve is that it can be defined as the process of projection from an (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-degree standard Bezier curve to the nnn-th dimensional plane. So how can this be done?

To show this, assume there are n+1n+1n+1 points in the mmm-th dimensional space, i.e., pi(x1(i),x2(i),⋯ ,xm(i))\mathbf{p}_i(x^{(i)}_1, x^{(i)}_2, \cdots, x^{(i)}_m)pi​(x1(i)​,x2(i)​,⋯,xm(i)​) and its corresponding weight w(i)w^{(i)}w(i). We append the weight to the coordinate and multiply it with each element in the vector to make up the homogeneous coordinate, denoted by pi′(w(i)x1(i),w(i)x2(i),⋯ ,w(i)xm(i),w(i))=w(i)pi\mathbf{p}'_i(w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_1, w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_2, \cdots, w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_m, w^{(i)})=w^{(i)}\mathbf{p}_ipi′​(w(i)x1(i)​,w(i)x2(i)​,⋯,w(i)xm(i)​,w(i))=w(i)pi​. Using the n+1n+1n+1 points in the m+1m+1m+1 dimensional homogeneous space, we can obtain the Bezier curve:

B~(t)=∑i=0nbi,n(t)pi′=∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)pi=(∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)x1(i)∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)x2(i)⋯∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)xm(i)∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i))\mathbf{\tilde{B}}(t)=\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)\mathbf{p}'_i=\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}\mathbf{p}_i=\begin{pmatrix} \sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_1\\ \sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_2\\ \cdots\\ \sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_m\\ \sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)} \end{pmatrix} B~(t)=i=0∑n​bi,n​(t)pi′​=i=0∑n​bi,n​(t)w(i)pi​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)x1(i)​∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)x2(i)​⋯∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)xm(i)​∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​

Note that this Bezier curve is in the m+1m+1m+1-th space, but what we really need is in the mmm-th space, which is the original dimension of control points. So we can project this curve into the the one that is in the mmm-th space, by dividing all elements by the value of the last element. Now the new curve becomes:

Bˉ(t)=∑i=0nbi,n(t)pi′∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)=∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)pi∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)=(∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)x1(i)/∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)x2(i)/∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)⋯∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)xm(i)/∑i=0nbi,n(t)w(i)1)\mathbf{\bar{B}}(t)=\frac{\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)\mathbf{p}'_i}{\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}}= \frac{\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}\mathbf{p}_i}{\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}}=\begin{pmatrix} \sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_1/\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}\\ \sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_2/\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}\\ \cdots\\ \sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}x^{(i)}_m/\sum_{i=0}^nb_{i,n}(t)w^{(i)}\\ 1 \end{pmatrix} Bˉ(t)=∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)pi′​​=∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)pi​​=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)x1(i)​/∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)x2(i)​/∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)⋯∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)xm(i)​/∑i=0n​bi,n​(t)w(i)1​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​

The first mmm elements now comprise the mmm dimensions of the new Bezier curve, and this is exactly B(t)\mathbf{B}(t)B(t) we’ve defined above. From this derivation, we know that rational Bezier curve is kind of a projection from a higher space into a lower space, where the shape of curve is controlled by the weights.

We will show in later sections that rational Bezier curves are a special case of NURBS curves, and modifying a control point of a rational Bezier curve will lead to a global curve change.

Approximating circular arcs

Symmetrical 2D

A cubic Bézier curve can be used to approximate a circular arc. Let’s first start with a simple case: the arc starts at point a\mathbf{a}a and ends at points b\mathbf{b}b, placed at equal distances above and below the xxx-axis in the first quadrant, spanning an arc of angle θ=2ϕ\theta=2\phiθ=2ϕ. The radius is RRR.

Assume the additional control points are a′\mathbf{a}'a′ and b′\mathbf{b}'b′, and their indices are respectively (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and (x,−y)(x, -y)(x,−y). Note that a(x^,y^),b(x^,−y^)\mathbf{a}(\hat{x},\hat{y}), \mathbf{b}(\hat{x},-\hat{y})a(x^,y^​),b(x^,−y^​), or a(Rcos⁡ϕ,Rsin⁡ϕ),b(Rcos⁡ϕ,−Rsin⁡ϕ)\mathbf{a}(R\cos\phi, R\sin\phi), \mathbf{b}(R\cos\phi, -R\sin\phi)a(Rcosϕ,Rsinϕ),b(Rcosϕ,−Rsinϕ).

According to the expanded Bézier curve expression:

B(t)=(1−t)3p0+3(1−t)2tp1+3(1−t)t2p2+t3p3, 0≤t≤1\mathbf{B}(t)=(1-t)^3\mathbf{p}_0+3(1-t)^2t\mathbf{p}_1+3(1-t)t^2\mathbf{p}_2+t^3\mathbf{p}_3,~0\le t\le 1 B(t)=(1−t)3p0​+3(1−t)2tp1​+3(1−t)t2p2​+t3p3​, 0≤t≤1

we have B(1/2)=(R,0)\mathbf{B}(1/2)=(R,0)B(1/2)=(R,0), which gives:

On the other hand, according to the derivative of a cubic Bézier curve B′(t)=−3(1−t)2a+3(1−t)(1−3t)a′+3t(2−2t)b′+3t2b\mathbf{B}'(t)=-3(1-t)^2\mathbf{a}+3(1-t)(1-3t)\mathbf{a}'+3t(2-2t)\mathbf{b}'+3t^2\mathbf{b}B′(t)=−3(1−t)2a+3(1−t)(1−3t)a′+3t(2−2t)b′+3t2b, we know the derivative at t=0t=0t=0 is 3(a′−a)3(\mathbf{a}'-\mathbf{a})3(a′−a). It is equal to the tangent at a\mathbf{a}a multiplied by some coefficient kkk:

However, we highlight that the resulting curve is not exactly a perfect circular arc, which means that there are small deviations from a perfect circular arc. Assuming the radius is 111 and p(t)=(x(t),y(t))\mathbf{p}(t)=(x(t), y(t))p(t)=(x(t),y(t)) as the approximate planar parametric curve, we can use the quantity Ψ(t)=∣x(t)2+y(t)2−1∣\Psi(t)=|x(t)^2+y(t)^2-1|Ψ(t)=∣x(t)2+y(t)2−1∣ as a measure of the error of approximation. The non-absolute version is defined as ψ(t)=x(t)2+y(t)2−1\psi(t)=x(t)^2+y(t)^2-1ψ(t)=x(t)2+y(t)2−1. Both refer to the error.

Asymmetrical 2D

Now we’ve obtained the control points a′(x,y)\mathbf{a}'(x,y)a′(x,y) and b′(x,−y)\mathbf{b}'(x,-y)b′(x,−y).

What about a\mathbf{a}a and b\mathbf{b}b are not symmetrical? Assume the angle of a\mathbf{a}a is θ\thetaθ and the angle spanned by the arc is ϕ\phiϕ, where the end point is b\mathbf{b}b. We can first rotate both a\mathbf{a}a and b\mathbf{b}b by −(θ+ϕ2)-\left(\theta+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)−(θ+2ϕ​). This now becomes the case discussed above. We can calculate the index of a(x,y)\mathbf{a}(x,y)a(x,y) after being rotated:

a~=[x~y~]=[cos⁡Φ−sin⁡Φsin⁡Φcos⁡Φ][xy],  Φ←−(θ+ϕ2),x=Rcos⁡θ,y=Rsin⁡θ\tilde{\mathbf{a}}=\begin{bmatrix}\tilde{x}\\\tilde{y}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\Phi & -\sin\Phi\\\sin\Phi & \cos\Phi\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x\\y\end{bmatrix},~~\Phi\gets-\left(\theta+\frac{\phi}{2}\right), x=R\cos\theta, y=R\sin\theta a~=[x~y~​​]=[cosΦsinΦ​−sinΦcosΦ​][xy​],  Φ←−(θ+2ϕ​),x=Rcosθ,y=Rsinθ

The rotated b~\tilde{\mathbf{b}}b~ will be (x~,−y~)⊤(\tilde{x},-\tilde{y})^\top(x~,−y~​)⊤.

Now we can follow the aforementioned process to calculate the control points:

a~′=(4R−x~3,(R−x~)(3R−x~)3y~),b~′=(4R−x~3,−(R−x~)(3R−x~)3y~)\tilde{\mathbf{a}}'=\left(\frac{4R-\tilde{x}}{3},\frac{(R-\tilde{x})(3R-\tilde{x})}{3\tilde{y}}\right), \tilde{\mathbf{b}}'=\left(\frac{4R-\tilde{x}}{3},-\frac{(R-\tilde{x})(3R-\tilde{x})}{3\tilde{y}}\right) a~′=(34R−x~​,3y~​(R−x~)(3R−x~)​),b~′=(34R−x~​,−3y~​(R−x~)(3R−x~)​)

Last, we rotate a~′\tilde{\mathbf{a}}'a~′ and b~′\tilde{\mathbf{b}}'b~′ back to the original positions:

a′=[cos⁡Φsin⁡Φ−sin⁡Φcos⁡Φ]a~′,  b′=[cos⁡Φsin⁡Φ−sin⁡Φcos⁡Φ]b~′\mathbf{a}'=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\Phi & \sin\Phi\\-\sin\Phi & \cos\Phi\end{bmatrix}\tilde{\mathbf{a}}',~~\mathbf{b}'=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\Phi & \sin\Phi\\-\sin\Phi & \cos\Phi\end{bmatrix}\tilde{\mathbf{b}}' a′=[cosΦ−sinΦ​sinΦcosΦ​]a~′,  b′=[cosΦ−sinΦ​sinΦcosΦ​]b~′

Besides using transformation and rotation, we can also utilize another approach to calculate the control points, with which we can eliminate the need of transforming points and directly getting to the absolute coordinates.[2]

Let us assume the starting point a(1,0)\mathbf{a}(1, 0)a(1,0), end point b(cos⁡α,sin⁡α)\mathbf{b}(\cos\alpha, \sin\alpha)b(cosα,sinα), and two unknown control points a′=a+L(0,1)⊤\mathbf{a}'=\mathbf{a}+L(0,1)^\topa′=a+L(0,1)⊤, b′=b−L(−sin⁡α,cos⁡α)⊤\mathbf{b}'=\mathbf{b}-L(-\sin\alpha,\cos\alpha)^\topb′=b−L(−sinα,cosα)⊤, where LLL is the Euclidean length of two vectors a′−a\mathbf{a}'-\mathbf{a}a′−a and b′−b\mathbf{b}'-\mathbf{b}b′−b. Plugging these four points into the Bezier curve, we have:

giving p(t)=(x(t),y(t))\mathbf{p}(t)=(x(t),y(t))p(t)=(x(t),y(t)). We can then directly compute the non-absolute version error ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t) as:

ψ(t)=15a(1−t)4t2+20b(1−t)3t3+15a(1−t)2t4\psi(t)=15a(1-t)^4t^2+20b(1-t)^3t^3+15a(1-t)^2t^4 ψ(t)=15a(1−t)4t2+20b(1−t)3t3+15a(1−t)2t4

where a=15(3L2+2Lsin⁡α−2(1−cos⁡α))a=\frac{1}{5}(3L^2+2L\sin\alpha-2(1-\cos\alpha))a=51​(3L2+2Lsinα−2(1−cosα)) and b=110(−9L2cos⁡α+18Lsin⁡α−10(1−cos⁡α))b=\frac{1}{10}(-9L^2\cos\alpha+18L\sin\alpha-10(1-\cos\alpha))b=101​(−9L2cosα+18Lsinα−10(1−cosα)). We choose LLL so that ψ(12)=0\psi(\frac{1}{2})=0ψ(21​)=0. Of course you can use other metrics to minimize this error, but ψ(12)=0\psi(\frac{1}{2})=0ψ(21​)=0 is a simple and intuitive choice. We can solve LLL as follows:

When we choose L=43tan⁡(α4)L=\frac{4}{3}\tan\left(\frac{\alpha}{4}\right)L=34​tan(4α​), the resulting Bezier curve will never enter inside the circle. Then the error is given by:

ψ(t)=16t2(1−t)2(1−2t)2sin⁡6α4cos⁡2α4\psi(t)=16t^2(1-t)^2(1-2t)^2\frac{\sin^6\frac{\alpha}{4}}{\cos^2\frac{\alpha}{4}} ψ(t)=16t2(1−t)2(1−2t)2cos24α​sin64α​​

By differentiating ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t) and solving ψ′(t)=0\psi'(t)=0ψ′(t)=0, we find ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t) obtains its maximum at t~=(3±3)/6\tilde{t}=(3\pm\sqrt{3})/6t~=(3±3​)/6 and the maximum is 427sin⁡6α4cos⁡2α4\frac{4}{27}\frac{\sin^6\frac{\alpha}{4}}{\cos^2\frac{\alpha}{4}}274​cos24α​sin64α​​. This implies that when α\alphaα is small, we have cos⁡α∼1\cos\alpha\sim 1cosα∼1 and sin⁡α∼α\sin\alpha\sim \alphasinα∼α, showing that the error decreases at the speed of the sixth order of circular angle α\alphaα. But when α\alphaα approches a full circle, i.e., α→2π\alpha\to 2\piα→2π, the error grows without bounds.

Returning to the more general case where the angle of a\mathbf{a}a is θ\thetaθ and the angle spanned by a\mathbf{a}a and b\mathbf{b}b is ϕ\phiϕ, or in other words a(Rcos⁡θ,Rsin⁡θ)\mathbf{a}(R\cos\theta, R\sin\theta)a(Rcosθ,Rsinθ) and b(Rcos⁡(θ+ϕ),Rsin⁡(θ+ϕ))\mathbf{b}(R\cos(\theta+\phi), R\sin(\theta+\phi))b(Rcos(θ+ϕ),Rsin(θ+ϕ)), we can similarly compute the control points a′\mathbf{a}'a′ and b′\mathbf{b}'b′:

Recall that the choice of L=43tan⁡(α4)L=\frac{4}{3}\tan\left(\frac{\alpha}{4}\right)L=34​tan(4α​) restrains the generated curve outside the circle. This can result in an error larger than expected. In fact, we can reduce the error by slightly “pushing” the curve in towards. We achieve this by multiple all the control points with a coefficient ρ\rhoρ: p(t)=(ρx(t),ρy(t))\mathbf{p}(t)=(\rho x(t), \rho y(t))p(t)=(ρx(t),ρy(t)). This gives us the new error ψ2(t)=(ρx(t))2+(ρy(t))2−1=ρ2ψ1(t)+ρ2−1\psi_2(t)=(\rho x(t))^2+(\rho y(t))^2-1=\rho^2 \psi_1(t)+\rho^2-1ψ2​(t)=(ρx(t))2+(ρy(t))2−1=ρ2ψ1​(t)+ρ2−1.

Note that ψ2(t)\psi_2(t)ψ2​(t) attains its extreme values at the same points as ψ1(t)\psi_1(t)ψ1​(t), i.e., t~=(3±3)/6\tilde{t}=(3\pm\sqrt{3})/6t~=(3±3​)/6, and we can compute them as:

We expect the overall error to be reduced by setting the minimum, i.e. ψ2(0)\psi_2(0)ψ2​(0) at the right opposite side of the maximum value, i.e. ψ2(t~)\psi_2(\tilde{t})ψ2​(t~). We then have:

ψ2(0)+ψ2(t~)=0⇒ρ2(ϵ1+2)=2⇒ρ=22+ϵ1\psi_2(0)+\psi_2(\tilde{t})=0\Rightarrow \rho^2(\epsilon_1+2)=2\Rightarrow \rho=\sqrt{\frac{2}{2+\epsilon_1}} ψ2​(0)+ψ2​(t~)=0⇒ρ2(ϵ1​+2)=2⇒ρ=2+ϵ1​2​​

When we have ρ\rhoρ set up, we can readily compute the maximum value ϵ2=2sin⁡6α427cos⁡2α4+2sin⁡6α4\epsilon_2=\frac{2\sin^6\frac{\alpha}{4}}{27\cos^2\frac{\alpha}{4}+2\sin^6\frac{\alpha}{4}}ϵ2​=27cos24α​+2sin64α​2sin64α​​. When α\alphaα is small, ϵ2≈12ϵ1\epsilon_2\approx \frac{1}{2}\epsilon_1ϵ2​≈21​ϵ1​, which significantly reduces the maximum error.

3D Space

The three-dimension case is more complicated because four control points will form a Bezier curve in 3D space. We should put one constraint on the points: the curve made up of these control points lie in the 2D space.

Cubic Hermite splines

Cubic Hermite splines construct a curve based on two points along with their respecive tangents.

Suppose the given starting point is p0\mathbf{p}_0p0​ at t=0t=0t=0 and ending point p1\mathbf{p}_1p1​ at t=1t=1t=1, as well as the starting tangent d0\mathbf{d}_0d0​ and d1\mathbf{d}_1d1​. The fitted cubic polynomial can be defined by:

p(t)=(2t3−3t2+1)p0+(t3−2t2+t)d0+(−2t3+3t2)p1+(t3−t2)d1\mathbf{p}(t)=(2t^3-3t^2+1)\mathbf{p}_0+(t^3-2t^2+t)\mathbf{d}_0+(-2t^3+3t^2)\mathbf{p}_1+(t^3-t^2)\mathbf{d}_1 p(t)=(2t3−3t2+1)p0​+(t3−2t2+t)d0​+(−2t3+3t2)p1​+(t3−t2)d1​

Proof is quite simple. Assume our function is p(t)=at3+bt2+ct+d\mathbf{p}(t)=at^3+bt^2+ct+dp(t)=at3+bt2+ct+d, and given that p(0)=p0,p(1)=p1,p′(0)=d0,p′(1)=d1\mathbf{p}(0)=\mathbf{p}_0, \mathbf{p}(1)=\mathbf{p}_1, \mathbf{p}'(0)=\mathbf{d}_0, \mathbf{p}'(1)=\mathbf{d}_1p(0)=p0​,p(1)=p1​,p′(0)=d0​,p′(1)=d1​, we have:

{d= p0a+b+c+d= p1c= d03a+2b+c= d1\begin{cases} d&=~\mathbf{p}_0\\ a+b+c+d&=~\mathbf{p}_1\\ c&=~\mathbf{d}_0\\ 3a+2b+c&=~\mathbf{d}_1 \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​da+b+c+dc3a+2b+c​= p0​= p1​= d0​= d1​​

Solving it gives us:

p(t)=(2p0−2p1+d0+d1)t3+(−3p0+3p1−2d0−d1)t2+d0t+p0\mathbf{p}(t)=(2\mathbf{p}_0-2\mathbf{p}_1+\mathbf{d}_0+\mathbf{d}_1)t^3+(-3\mathbf{p}_0+3\mathbf{p}_1-2\mathbf{d}_0-\mathbf{d}_1)t^2+\mathbf{d}_0t+\mathbf{p}_0 p(t)=(2p0​−2p1​+d0​+d1​)t3+(−3p0​+3p1​−2d0​−d1​)t2+d0​t+p0​

Rearranging p(t)\mathbf{p}(t)p(t) gives the equation proposed at the beginning.

We can also reformulate p(t)\mathbf{p}(t)p(t) in terms of Bézier curves with respect to the four control points p0,p0+13d0,p1−13d1,p1\mathbf{p}_0, \mathbf{p}_0+\frac{1}{3}\mathbf{d}_0, \mathbf{p}_1-\frac{1}{3}\mathbf{d}_1,\mathbf{p}_1p0​,p0​+31​d0​,p1​−31​d1​,p1​. To show this, recall that a cubic Bézier curve can be expresses as:

B(t)=∑i=0npibi,n(t), bi,n(t)=(ni)(1−t)n−iti\mathbf{B}(t)=\sum_{i=0}^n\mathbf{p}_ib_{i,n}(t), ~b_{i,n}(t)=\binom{n}{i}(1-t)^{n-i}t^i B(t)=i=0∑n​pi​bi,n​(t), bi,n​(t)=(in​)(1−t)n−iti

We can rewrite p(t)\mathbf{p}(t)p(t) as follows:

p(t)=(2t3−3t2+1)p0+(t3−2t2+t)d0+(−2t3+3t2)p1+(t3−t2)d1=(b0,3(t)+b1,3(t))p0+13b1,3(t)d0+(b2,3(t)+b3,3(t))p1−13b2,3(t)d1=b0,3(t)p0+b1,3(t)(p0+13d0)+b2,3(t)(p1−13d1)+b3,3(t)p1\begin{aligned} \mathbf{p}(t)&=(2t^3-3t^2+1)\mathbf{p}_0+(t^3-2t^2+t)\mathbf{d}_0+(-2t^3+3t^2)\mathbf{p}_1+(t^3-t^2)\mathbf{d}_1\\ &=(b_{0,3}(t)+b_{1,3}(t))\mathbf{p}_0+\frac{1}{3}b_{1,3}(t)\mathbf{d}_0+(b_{2,3}(t)+b_{3,3}(t))\mathbf{p}_1-\frac{1}{3}b_{2,3}(t)\mathbf{d}_1\\ &=b_{0,3}(t)\mathbf{p}_0+b_{1,3}(t)\left(\mathbf{p}_0+\frac{1}{3}\mathbf{d}_0\right)+b_{2,3}(t)\left(\mathbf{p}_1-\frac{1}{3}\mathbf{d}_1\right)+b_{3,3}(t)\mathbf{p}_1 \end{aligned} p(t)​=(2t3−3t2+1)p0​+(t3−2t2+t)d0​+(−2t3+3t2)p1​+(t3−t2)d1​=(b0,3​(t)+b1,3​(t))p0​+31​b1,3​(t)d0​+(b2,3​(t)+b3,3​(t))p1​−31​b2,3​(t)d1​=b0,3​(t)p0​+b1,3​(t)(p0​+31​d0​)+b2,3​(t)(p1​−31​d1​)+b3,3​(t)p1​​

This shows that a cubic Bézier curve that patches the control points in the middle determines the tangents of the interpolation curve at the respective outer points.[3]

B-splines

Definition and Properties

B-spline stands for basic splines. Let t0,t1,t2,⋯ ,tmt_0, t_1, t_2, \cdots, t_mt0​,t1​,t2​,⋯,tm​ be a series of nondecreasing knots, where t0=0,tm=1t_0=0, t_m=1t0​=0,tm​=1 are the two ends in the spline. The iii-th B-spline of degree ppp, written as Ni,p(u)N_{i,p}(u)Ni,p​(u), is defined recursively as follows:

Ni,0(t)={1,ti≤t<ti+10,elseNi,p(t)=t−titi+p−tiNi,p−1(t)+ti+p+1−tti+p+1−ti+1Ni+1,p−1(t)\begin{aligned} N_{i,0}(t)&=\begin{cases}1,&t_i\le t<t_{i+1}\\0,&\text{else}\end{cases}\\ N_{i,p}(t)&=\frac{t-t_i}{t_{i+p}-t_i}N_{i, p-1}(t)+\frac{t_{i+p+1}-t}{t_{i+p+1}-t_{i+1}}N_{i+1,p-1}(t) \end{aligned} Ni,0​(t)Ni,p​(t)​={1,0,​ti​≤t<ti+1​else​=ti+p​−ti​t−ti​​Ni,p−1​(t)+ti+p+1​−ti+1​ti+p+1​−t​Ni+1,p−1​(t)​

From the following diagram, we know that the polynomial Ni,p(t)N_{i,p}(t)Ni,p​(t) covers the span of range [ti,tt+p+1)[t_i, t_{t+p+1})[ti​,tt+p+1​). Thus, Ni,p(t)N_{i,p}(t)Ni,p​(t) is non-zero on [ti,tt+p+1)[t_i, t_{t+p+1})[ti​,tt+p+1​). And reversely, on any knot span [ti,ti+1)[t_i, t_{i+1})[ti​,ti+1​), at most p+1p+1p+1 degree ppp basic functions are non-zero, i.e., Ni−p,p(t),Ni−p+1,p(t),⋯ ,Ni,p(t)N_{i-p,p}(t), N_{i-p+1,p}(t), \cdots, N_{i,p}(t)Ni−p,p​(t),Ni−p+1,p​(t),⋯,Ni,p​(t).

[t0,t1)−N0,0N0,1[t1,t2)−N1,0N0,2N1,1N0,3[t2,t3)−N2,0N1,2N0,4N2,1N1,3[t3,t4)−N3,0N2,2N3,1[t4,t5)−N4,0\begin{matrix} [t_0,t_1) & - & N_{0,0} & & & &\\ & & & N_{0,1} & & &\\ [t_1,t_2) & - & N_{1,0} & & N_{0,2} & &\\ & & & N_{1,1} & & N_{0,3} &\\ [t_2,t_3) & - & N_{2,0} & & N_{1,2} & & N_{0,4}\\ & & & N_{2,1} & & N_{1,3} &\\ [t_3,t_4) & - & N_{3,0} & & N_{2,2} & &\\ & & & N_{3,1} & & &\\ [t_4,t_5) & - & N_{4,0} & & & &\\ \end{matrix} [t0​,t1​)[t1​,t2​)[t2​,t3​)[t3​,t4​)[t4​,t5​)​−−−−−​N0,0​N1,0​N2,0​N3,0​N4,0​​N0,1​N1,1​N2,1​N3,1​​N0,2​N1,2​N2,2​​N0,3​N1,3​​N0,4​​

B-spline has the following important properties:

  • Ni,p(t)N_{i,p}(t)Ni,p​(t) is a degree ppp polynomial in ttt.
  • Ni,p(t)N_{i,p}(t)Ni,p​(t) is non-negative on [ti,ti+p+1)[t_i,t_{i+p+1})[ti​,ti+p+1​).
  • On any knot span [ti,ti+1)[t_i, t_{i+1})[ti​,ti+1​), at most p+1p+1p+1 degree ppp basic functions are non-zero, i.e., Ni−p,p(t),Ni−p+1,p(t),⋯ ,Ni,p(t)N_{i-p,p}(t), N_{i-p+1,p}(t), \cdots, N_{i,p}(t)Ni−p,p​(t),Ni−p+1,p​(t),⋯,Ni,p​(t).
  • The sum of all non-zero degree ppp basic functions on span [ti,ti+1)[t_i,t_{i+1})[ti​,ti+1​) is 1. That is, ∀p,∑k=i−piNk,p(t)=1\forall p,\sum_{k=i-p}^iN_{k,p}(t)=1∀p,∑k=i−pi​Nk,p​(t)=1.
  • If the number of knots is m+1m+1m+1 and given degree ppp, all basic functions with degree ppp are N0,p(t),⋯ ,Nm−p−1,p(t)N_{0,p}(t),\cdots,N_{m-p-1,p}(t)N0,p​(t),⋯,Nm−p−1,p​(t).
  • At a knot of multiplicity kkk, basic function Ni,p(t)N_{i,p}(t)Ni,p​(t) is Cp−k\mathsf{C}^{p-k}Cp−k continous.
  • At each internal knot of multiplicity kkk, the number of non-zero basic functions is at most p−k+1p-k+1p−k+1, where ppp is the degree of basic functions.

B-spline Curves

Given n+1n+1n+1 control points p0,p1,⋯ ,pn\mathbf{p}_0, \mathbf{p}_1, \cdots, \mathbf{p}_np0​,p1​,⋯,pn​ and a series of m+1m+1m+1 knots t0,t1,t2,⋯ ,tmt_0, t_1, t_2, \cdots, t_mt0​,t1​,t2​,⋯,tm​, the B-spline curve of degree ppp can be defined as:

B(t)=∑i=0nNi,p(t)pi\mathbf{B}(t)=\sum_{i=0}^nN_{i,p}(t)\mathbf{p}_i B(t)=i=0∑n​Ni,p​(t)pi​

Note that when i=ni=ni=n, Nn,p(t)N_{n,p}(t)Nn,p​(t) will be last basic function with degree ppp, that is to satisfy n=m−p−1n=m-p-1n=m−p−1, or m=n+p+1m=n+p+1m=n+p+1. In other words, a B-spline curve of degree ppp with n+1n+1n+1 points must be associated with n+p+2n+p+2n+p+2 knots t0,t1,⋯ ,tn+p+2t_0, t_1, \cdots, t_{n+p+2}t0​,t1​,⋯,tn+p+2​; or if m+1m+1m+1 knots and n+1n+1n+1 control points are given, the degree will be p=m−n−1p=m-n-1p=m−n−1.

Typically, B-spline curves can be categorized into three types: open curve, clamped curve and closed curve.

  • Open B-spline curves: the generated curve does not connect to the first and last control point.
  • Clamped B-spline curves: the curve is connected to the first and last control point and is also tangent to them. To be a clamped curve, the first and last knot must be of multiplicity p+1p+1p+1 (recall that there are in all n+p+2n+p+2n+p+2 knots).
  • Closed B-spline curves: the generated curve forms a closed loop.
